abstract.text: A standard view controller whose interface lets the user compose and send SMS or MMS messages.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Use an

object to display the standard message composition interface inside your app. Before presenting the interface, populate the fields with the set of initial recipients and the message you want to send. After presenting the interface, a person can edit your initial values before sending the message.

The composition interface doesn’t guarantee the delivery of your message; it only lets you construct the initial message and present it for a person’s approval. The person may opt to cancel the composition interface which discards the message and its contents. If the person opts to send the message, the Messages app takes on the responsibility of sending the message.
You must not modify the view hierarchy presented by this view controller. However, you can customize the appearance of the interface using the
protocol.
An alternate way to compose SMS messages is to create and open a URL that uses the
scheme. URLs of that type go directly to the Messages app, which uses your URL to configure the message. For information about the structure of
URLs, see

content.text: Checking the availability of the composition interface

inlineContent.text: Before presenting the message compose view controller, always call the

method to see if the person configured the current device to send messages. If the user’s device isn’t set up to send or receive messages, you can notify the user or disable the messaging features in your application. You shouldn’t attempt to use this interface if the
method returns
. If messaging is available, you can also use the
and
methods to determine if those specific messaging features are available.

content.text: Configuring and displaying the composition interface

inlineContent.text: After verifying that message services are available, you can create and configure the message composition view controller and then present it like any other view controller. Use the methods of this class to specify the message’s recipients and the contents of the message. If attachments or a subject line are supported, you can set values for them as well. The sample code below shows how to configure the composition interface and present it modally. Always assign a delegate to the
property, because the delegate is responsible for dismissing the composition interface later. The delegate object must conform to the
protocol.

code: // Configure the fields of the interface.
// Configure the fields of the interface.

inlineContent.text: The message compose view controller isn’t dismissed automatically. When the user taps the buttons to send the message or cancel the interface, the message compose view controller calls the

method of its delegate. Your implementation of that method must dismiss the view controller explicitly, as shown in the sample code below. You can also use this method to check the result of the operation.

code: // Check the result or perform other tasks.
// Dismiss the message compose view controller.
// Check the result or perform other tasks.    // Dismiss the message compose view controller.

inlineContent.text: For more information on how to present and dismiss view controllers, see

content.text: Detecting changes to the availability of messaging

inlineContent.text: Add an observer to the
notification to get notified of changes to the messaging capabilities of the current device. The system delivers that notification to your observer when the status of messaging changes.

abstract.text: A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
Posted when the value returned by the  class method has changed.
A false value.
Create a user interface for composing email and text messages, so users can edit and send messages without leaving your app.
A standard view controller whose interface lets the user compose and send SMS or MMS messages.
Attaches arbitrary content to the message.
Attaches a specified file to the message.
Returns an array of dictionaries that describe the properties of an attachment.
The initial content of the message.
Indicates whether or not messages can include attachments.
Indicates whether or not messages can include subject lines, according to the user’s configuration in Settings.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the current device is capable of sending text messages.
Disables the camera/attachment button in the message composition view.
Indicates whether or not the message can accept a file, with the specified UTI, as an attachment.
A message object from your iMessage app extension.
The delegate to which message-related notifications should be sent.
An array of strings that contains the initial recipients of the message.
Configures the instance of a view for Unified Payments Interface (UPI) device validation.
The initial subject of the message.
The key for the alternate filename for the file-based item attached to the message.
The URL for the item that is attached to the message.
An interface for responding to user interactions with a message compose view controller.
Tells the delegate that the user finished composing the message.
The value of this key is a number object that contains a Boolean value.
Posted when the value returned by the
class method has changed.
A container view controller that defines a stack-based scheme for navigating hierarchical content.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
Methods for adding objects to your state restoration archives.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
